title: NFL on NBC
text:
The NFL on NBC is the branding used for broadcasts of <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) games that are produced by <a href="NBC%20Sports">NBC Sports</a>, and televised on the <a href="NBC">NBC</a> television network in the United States.
NBC had sporadically carried NFL games as early as <a href="1939%20NFL%20season">1939</a>, including the championship and Pro Bowl through the 1950s and early 1960s. Beginning in <a href="1965%20American%20Football%20League%20season">1965</a>, NBC signed an agreement to carry the <a href="American%20Football%20League">American Football League</a> (AFL)'s telecasts, which carried over with the <a href="American%20Football%20Conference">American Football Conference</a> (AFC) when the <a href="AFL-NFL%20merger">AFL merged with the NFL</a>. NBC would continuously carry the AFL/AFC's Sunday afternoon games from 1965 through the <a href="1997%20NFL%20season">1997 season</a>, after which NBC lost the AFC contract to <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a>.
NFL coverage returned to NBC on August 6, <a href="2006%20NFL%20season">2006</a>, under the title <a href="NBC%20Sunday%20Night%20Football">NBC Sunday Night Football</a>, beginning with its coverage of the preseason <a href="Pro%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20Game">Pro Football Hall of Fame Game</a>. From <a href="2016%20NFL%20season">2016</a> to <a href="2017%20NFL%20season">2017</a>, NBC added a five-game "<a href="Thursday%20Night%20Football">Thursday Night Football</a>" package to its offerings supplementing two Thursday games that were already part of the "Sunday Night Football" package. Game coverage is usually preceded by the pregame show "<a href="Football%20Night%20in%20America">Football Night in America</a>".
History.
Beginnings through the 1950s.
NBC's coverage of the National Football League (which has aired under numerous program titles and formats) actually goes back to the beginnings of the network's relationship with the league in <a href="1939%20NFL%20season">1939</a>, when its New York City <a href="flagship%20%28broadcasting%29">flagship station</a>, then known as W2XBS (now <a href="WNBC">WNBC</a>) aired the first televised professional football game between the <a href="1939%20Philadelphia%20Eagles%20season">Philadelphia Eagles</a> and the now-defunct <a href="1939%20Brooklyn%20Dodgers%20%28NFL%29%20season">Brooklyn Dodgers</a> football team. Even before this, in <a href="1934%20NFL%20season">1934</a>, <a href="NFL%20on%20NBC%20Radio">NBC Radio</a>'s <a href="Blue%20Network">Blue Network</a> had carried the <a href="1934%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Detroit Lions</a>' inaugural <a href="NFL%20on%20Thanksgiving%20Day">Thanksgiving game</a> nationwide.
By <a href="1955%20NFL%20season">1955</a>, NBC became the television home to the <a href="NFL%20Championship%20Game">NFL Championship Game</a>, the precursor to the <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a>, paying US$100,000 to the league for the rights. The network had taken over the broadcast rights from the <a href="NFL%20on%20DuMont">DuMont Television Network</a>, which had struggled to give the league a national audience (NBC's coverage of proto-<a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">Canadian Football League</a> games from <a href="1954%20in%20Canadian%20football">the year prior</a> was more widely available at the time) and was on the brink of failure; the NFL's associations with NBC (as well as with <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a>) proved to be a boost to the league's popularity. For the <a href="1957%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1957 NFL Championship Game</a>, <a href="Van%20Patrick">Van Patrick</a> and <a href="Ken%20Coleman">Ken Coleman</a> split a half of the play-by-play duties and <a href="Red%20Grange">Red Grange</a>, normally on play-by-play for <a href="1957%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">Chicago Bears</a> games on <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a>, assumed the color commentator role for this game. The <a href="1958%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1958 NFL Championship Game</a>, played at <a href="Yankee%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Yankee Stadium</a>, between the <a href="1958%20Baltimore%20Colts%20season">Baltimore Colts</a> and the <a href="1958%20New%20York%20Giants%20season">New York Giants</a> went into sudden death overtime. This game, since known as the "Greatest Game Ever Played", was seen by many throughout the country and is credited with increasing the popularity of professional football in the late 1950s and early 1960s. <a href="Chris%20Schenkel">Chris Schenkel</a> called the first half while <a href="Chuck%20Thompson">Chuck Thompson</a> called the second half and overtime.
NBC televised the NFL Championship Game until <a href="1963%20NFL%20season">1963</a>. The contract for the title game was separate than the regular season contracts held by <a href="CBS">CBS</a>, which started televising NFL games in <a href="1956%20NFL%20season">1956</a>. Prior to <a href="1962%20NFL%20season">1962</a>, each team had its own individual television contract. (This was in contrast to the <a href="American%20Football%20League">American Football League</a> as well as established practice in <a href="college%20football">college football</a>, both of which forced all of their members to participate in a collective television contract. As the legality of such a collective contract was still in question at the time, and would eventually be <a href="NCAA%20v.%20Board%20of%20Regents%20of%20the%20University%20of%20Oklahoma">declared illegal in 1984</a>, the NFL did not pursue such a contract until Congress explicitly allowed for the NFL to do so, with conditions, in the <a href="Sports%20Broadcasting%20Act%20of%201961">Sports Broadcasting Act of 1961</a>.) NBC held individual team contracts with the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> and <a href="Baltimore%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a> in <a href="1959%20NFL%20season">1959</a>, <a href="1960%20NFL%20season">1960</a> and <a href="1961%20NFL%20season">1961</a>. While the games were <a href="blackout%20%28broadcasting%29">blacked out</a> in <a href="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a> and <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore</a>, they were broadcast on other NBC stations. In some cases, the game broadcast was seen on CBS in the visiting team's home region. NBC covered eleven games in 1960 and 13 games in 1961 in a "Game of the Week" format. NBC would take one week off due to its <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20NBC">coverage</a> of the <a href="List%20of%20World%20Series%20broadcasters">World Series</a>. During this era, NBC broadcast pre-recorded and edited hour-long broadcasts of NFL games in the off-season under the title "Best of Pro Football".
During this period, NBC also held the rights to the <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> (which was also under a separate contract from the NFL's regular season games and the NFL Championship Game) via the Los Angeles newspapers' charities. NBC televised the Pro Bowl following the <a href="1951%20NFL%20season">1951</a> and <a href="1952%20NFL%20season">1952 seasons</a> and again from the <a href="1957%20NFL%20season">1957</a> to <a href="1964%20NFL%20season">1964 seasons</a>. The <a href="1957%20Pro%20Bowl">1957 game</a> was offered to NBC, then <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a>. Both declined to carry the game. <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> was then offered to televise and accepted, but could not gain enough clearance of <a href="List%20of%20ABC%20television%20affiliates%20%28by%20U.S.%20state%29">affiliates</a> in time to make it a profitable venture. Thus they also dropped out and the game was not televised.
1960s.
At the <a href="1960%20NFL%20season">start</a> of the 1960s, 10 of the NFL's 13 NFL teams (including the brand new <a href="1960%20Dallas%20Cowboys%20season">Dallas Cowboys</a>) were aligned with <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a>, two joined forces with NBC (the aforementioned <a href="1960%20Baltimore%20Colts%20season">Colts</a> and the <a href="1960%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">Steelers</a>) and one (the <a href="1960%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">Cleveland Browns</a>) rejoined its partner, the <a href="Broadcast%20syndication">syndicated</a> <a href="Hughes%20Television%20Network">Sports Network</a>. NBC during this time period, employed <a href="Lindsey%20Nelson">Lindsey Nelson</a> and <a href="Frankie%20Albert">Frankie Albert</a> as their top broadcasting crew.
In Week 1 of the 1960 season, the <a href="1960%20Washington%20Redskins%20season">Washington</a>-Baltimore game was also seen on <a href="List%20of%20NBC%20television%20affiliates%20%28by%20U.S.%20state%29">NBC affiliates</a> in <a href="KSDK">St. Louis</a>, <a href="KNBC">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="WPXI">Pittsburgh</a>, <a href="KXAS-TV">Dallas-Ft. Worth</a> and <a href="WDIV-TV">Detroit</a>. For the following week, NBC's affiliates in <a href="KYW-TV">Philadelphia</a>, Dallas-Ft. Worth and <a href="WRC-TV">Washington</a> also carried <a href="1960%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">Chicago</a>-Baltimore game. There was no telecast in Week 3 as <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20NBC">NBC</a> was televising Game 4 of the <a href="1960%20Pittsburgh%20Pirates%20season">Pirates</a>-<a href="1960%20New%20York%20Yankees%20season">Yankees</a> <a href="1960%20World%20Series">World Series</a>. Week 4 saw NBC's <a href="WFRV-TV">Green Bay</a> and <a href="WTMJ-TV">Milwaukee</a> affiliates joining in on the <a href="1960%20Los%20Angeles%20Rams%20season">Los Angeles</a>-Baltimore game. For Week 5, NBC's <a href="WNBC">New York affiliate</a> also carried the Pittsburgh-Washington game. In Week 6, NBC's Philadelphia affiliate was a part of NBC's telecast of the <a href="1960%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">Green Bay Packers</a>-Steelers game. For the following week, <a href="WMAQ-TV">Chicago's NBC station</a> picked up NBC's Green Bay-Baltimore telecast. The <a href="KRON-TV">San Francisco Bay Area</a> also tuned into NBC's coverage of Baltimore-<a href="1960%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">Chicago</a> in Week 8. Meanwhile, <a href="WMAR-TV">Channel 2</a> in <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore</a> provide their own coverage locally of the Colts-Bears game, with Chuck Thompson and Bailey Goss on the call. In Week 9, <a href="WBAL-TV">WBAL</a> in Baltimore also carried the Cleveland-Pittsburgh game. On Cleveland's own syndicated network, the game was called by <a href="Ken%20Coleman">Ken Coleman</a> and <a href="Jimmy%20Dudley">Jimmy Dudley</a>. On <a href="NFL%20on%20Thanksgiving%20Day">Thanksgiving Day</a>, 1960, NBC's Green Bay, Milwaukee, Detroit and Los Angeles affiliates joined in on their <a href="1960%20San%20Francisco%2049ers%20season">San Francisco</a>-Baltimore telecast. In Week 11, NBC's Pittsburgh's station was also part of the coverage of the <a href="1960%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Detroit</a>-Baltimore game. For the following week, NBC's St. Louis, San Francisco and Green Bay stations carried the <a href="1960%20Philadelphia%20Eagles%20season">Philadelphia</a>-Pittsburgh game. In Week 13, NBC's Green Bay, Milwaukee, Los Angeles and Dallas/Ft. Worth affiliates all joined in for NBC's Pittsburgh-<a href="1960%20St.%20Louis%20Cardinals%20%28NFL%29%20season">St. Louis</a> telecast. 
On April 5, 1961, NBC was awarded a two-year contract (1961–62) for the radio and television rights to the NFL Championship Game, paying US$615,000 annually for the rights ($300,000 of which was to go directly into the <a href="NFL%20Player%20Benefit%20Plan">NFL Player Benefit Plan</a>). On May 23, 1963, NBC was awarded exclusive network broadcast rights for the 1963 NFL Championship Game for $926,000. For the <a href="1960%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1960 NFL Championship Game</a>, there was an early kickoff due to NFL officials preparing for potential of sudden death overtime. <a href="Franklin%20Field">Franklin Field</a> had no lights and sunset would normally occur around 4:35 p.m. at this time of year in <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>.
NBC continued to televise 13 Sundays involving either the <a href="1961%20Baltimore%20Colts%20season">Colts</a> and <a href="1961%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">Steelers</a> (the odd week was when NBC had the <a href="1961%20World%20Series">World Series</a>) in <a href="1961%20NFL%20season">1961</a>. This time, Lindsay Nelson was joined by Chuck Thompson on commentary. In Week 1, NBC's <a href="1961%20Los%20Angeles%20Rams%20season">Los Angeles</a>-Baltimore telecast was seen nationally except in NFL markets and the <a href="KCBS-TV">CBS Los Angeles</a> network region (which featured <a href="Bob%20Kelley">Bob Kelley</a> and <a href="Gil%20Stratton">Gil Stratton</a> on commentary). The exception to this would be if teams did not play on Sunday, then the NBC affiliate could carry their games in those markets as well. So if the Colts or Steelers (in this case the Steelers) were not on NBC and they were on the road, then an ad hoc regional network would be permitted to carry the game, either using its own crew or picking up the CBS feed and crew. In Week 2, NBC's affiliates in Chicago and Los Angeles also plugged into NBC's telecast of the <a href="1961%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Detroit</a>-Baltimore game. In Week 3, the Baltimore-<a href="1961%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">Green Bay</a> game was televised locally to Baltimore on WBAL 11. Apparently if Baltimore viewers wanted to see the World Series, they would have had to choose between <a href="WRC-TV">WRC 4</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington</a> or <a href="WGAL">WGAL 8</a> in <a href="Lancaster%2C%20Pennsylvania">Lancaster, Pennsylvania</a>. As previously mentioned, there was no NFL telecast on NBC due to coverage of Game 4 of the World Series. In Week 11, NBC's Green Bay, Milwaukee and Detroit affiliates were added to their <a href="1961%20St.%20Louis%20Cardinals%20%28NFL%29%20season">St. Louis</a>-Pittsburgh telecast. For Week 13, the telecast of the Pittsburgh-<a href="1961%20Washington%20Redskins%20season">Washington</a> game included Channel 4 in Los Angeles and Channel 11 in Baltimore. NBC's Week 14 telecast of the Pittsburgh-St. Louis included channel 4 in the Bay Area and channel 11 in Baltimore.
At the end of the 1964 season, NBC would carry the <a href="1965%20Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> one last time as the game was still the property of the Los Angeles Newspaper Charities. CBS not only won the deal to <a href="List%20of%20NFL%20Championship%20Game%20broadcasters">carry</a> the NFL Championship Game starting in <a href="1964%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1964</a> (which had been at NBC since <a href="1955%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1955</a>), but it would also begin televising the Pro Bowl after the <a href="1965%20NFL%20season">1965 season</a> as the NFL took control of the all-star tilt. NBC's 1965 Pro Bowl telecast was aired in color and featured <a href="Ken%20Coleman">Ken Coleman</a> and <a href="Gordy%20Soltau">Gordy Soltau</a> on the call.
NBC obtains the rights to the American Football League.
NBC resumed professional football telecasts on a regular basis in <a href="American%20Football%20League%20seasons%231965">1965</a>. On January 29, 1964, NBC signed a five-year deal with the <a href="American%20Football%20League">American Football League</a> (replacing <a href="American%20Football%20League%20on%20ABC">ABC</a> in that role), paying them US$36 million to televise its games; with this and the increased, heated battle over college prospects, both leagues negotiated a <a href="AFL%E2%80%93NFL%20merger">merger</a> agreement on June 8, 1966. Although they would not officially fully merge and adopt an interlocking schedule until <a href="1970%20NFL%20season">1970</a>, two of the conditions of the agreement were that the winners of each league's championship game would meet in a contest (which would eventually become known as the Super Bowl) to determine the "world champion of football", and that there would be a common <a href="NFL%20Draft">player draft</a>. <a href="Curt%20Gowdy">Curt Gowdy</a>, who had covered the first five seasons of the American Football League with broadcast partner <a href="Paul%20Christman">Paul Christman</a> on ABC, moved over to NBC in the fall of 1965. For the next decade, Gowdy was the lead play-by-play announcer for the network for both AFL football (AFC from 1970 onward) and <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20NBC">Major League Baseball</a> games; however, Gowdy also covered a wide range of sports, earning him the nickname of the "broadcaster of everything." Besides Paul Christman, Curt Gowdy's other football broadcast partners were <a href="Kyle%20Rote">Kyle Rote</a>, <a href="Al%20DeRogatis">Al DeRogatis</a>, <a href="Don%20Meredith">Don Meredith</a>, <a href="John%20Brodie">John Brodie</a> and <a href="Merlin%20Olsen">Merlin Olsen</a>.
The 1965 AFL season began many occasions through the years of NBC's October Sunday telecasts that being forced to shift to local stations and productions due to NBC's commitment to <a href="List%20of%20World%20Series%20broadcasters">postseason baseball</a>. For example, Week 5's game between <a href="1965%20Kansas%20City%20Chiefs%20season">Kansas City</a> and <a href="1965%20Denver%20Broncos%20season">Denver</a> was aired on <a href="Kansas%20City%2C%20Missouri">Kansas City</a>'s <a href="WDAF-TV">WDAF 4</a>. <a href="Charlie%20Jones%20%28sportscaster%29">Charlie Jones</a> and Ken Case were on the call for the Chiefs-Broncos game. And with NBC focusing color cameras for the <a href="1965%20World%20Series">World Series</a> in <a href="Dodger%20Stadium">Los Angeles</a>, it is likely that Week 5's <a href="1965%20San%20Diego%20Chargers%20season">San Diego</a>-<a href="1965%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo</a> game (called by Curt Gowdy and Paul Christman) was televised in black and white.
For the <a href="American%20Football%20League%20seasons%231966">1966 AFL season</a>, NBC would feature about 40 games in <a href="Color%20television">color</a>, including their three postseason telecasts. With massive wattage from the <a href="Miami%20Orange%20Bowl">Orange Bowl</a> floodlights, the <a href="1966%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">New York</a>-<a href="1966%20Miami%20Dolphins%20season">Miami</a> game (called by Curt Gowdy and Paul Christman) from Week 2 was likely the first pro football night game ever to be televised in color. With Game 4 of the <a href="1966%20World%20Series">1966 World Series</a> landing in Week 6 of the AFL season, and the AFL schedule reflects the priority. Therefore, the Miami-<a href="1966%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland</a> (called by Charlie Jones and Paul Christman) was seen after the World Series clincher, possibly already in progress. For Week 14, Curt Gowdy and Paul Christman called a late afternoon game in the <a href="Oakland%2C%20California">Oakland</a> (the Raiders were playing the Jets on December 3) on Saturday, flew a <a href="Red-eye%20flight">red-eye</a> to <a href="Boston">Boston</a>, and then called the <a href="1965%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo</a>-<a href="1965%20Boston%20Patriots%20season">Boston</a> game the next day at 1 p.m.
The introduction of the Super Bowl.
On December 13, 1966, the rights to the Super Bowl for four years were sold to CBS and NBC for $9.5 million. The first ever <a href="Super%20Bowl%20I">AFL-NFL World Championship Game</a> was played on January 15, 1967. Because <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a> held the rights to nationally televise NFL games and NBC had the rights to broadcast AFL games, it was decided by the newly-merged league to have both of them cover that first game (the only pro football game to have been carried nationally on more than one network until December 29, <a href="2007%20NFL%20season">2007</a>, with the <a href="2007%20New%20England%20Patriots-New%20York%20Giants%20game">New England Patriots-New York Giants</a> game, which aired on NBC, CBS and the <a href="NFL%20Network">NFL Network</a>). However, NBC was forced to broadcast the game over CBS' feed and cameras (CBS received prerogative to use its feed and camera angles since the Coliseum was home to the NFL's Rams), while only CBS' cameras and technical crew were allowed to work the game, although NBC was allowed to use its own commentators. As a result, NBC's crew had little to no control over how the game was broadcast. Each network used its own announcers: <a href="Ray%20Scott%20%28sportscaster%29">Ray Scott</a> (doing <a href="play-by-play">play-by-play</a> for the first half), <a href="Jack%20Whitaker">Jack Whitaker</a> (doing play-by-play for the second half) and <a href="Frank%20Gifford">Frank Gifford</a> providing commentary on CBS; while Curt Gowdy and Paul Christman did so for NBC. NBC did have some problems with the dual telecast; the network did not return in time from a <a href="halftime">halftime</a> commercial break for the start of the second half. Therefore, the first <a href="Kickoff%20%28American%20football%29">kickoff</a> was stopped by the game's officials and was redone once NBC returned to the broadcast.
Week 4 of the <a href="American%20Football%20League%20seasons%231967">1967 AFL season</a> coincided with the race for the <a href="American%20League">American League</a> pennant. NBC decided to focus on its <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20NBC">baseball coverage</a> instead of covering the early AFL games, thus resulting in Curt Gowdy calling the <a href="1967%20Minnesota%20Twins%20season">Twins</a>-<a href="1967%20Boston%20Red%20Sox%20season">Red Sox</a> game and <a href="Jim%20Simpson%20%28sportscaster%29">Jim Simpson</a> calling the <a href="1967%20California%20Angels%20season">Angels</a>-<a href="1967%20Detroit%20Tigers%20season">Tigers</a> game), while the AFL schedule resulted in the two early games (<a href="1967%20Denver%20Broncos%20season">Broncos</a>-<a href="1967%20Houston%20Oilers%20season">Oilers</a> and <a href="1967%20Miami%20Dolphins%20season">Dolphins</a>-<a href="1967%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">Jets</a> not being televised with another one, <a href="1967%20San%20Diego%20Chargers%20season">Chargers</a>-<a href="1967%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Bills</a> being a locally-televised game airing only in <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego</a> on then-NBC affiliate KOGO (now ABC affiliate <a href="KGTV">KGTV</a>).
The trio of Curt Gowdy, Kyle Rote and Al DeRogatis would each also handle two games in Week 1 of the <a href="American%20Football%20League%20seasons%231968">1968 AFL season</a>. All three teamed to call the <a href="1968%20Cincinnati%20Bengals%20season">Cincinnati</a>-<a href="1968%20San%20Diego%20Chargers%20season">San Diego</a> game on Thursday night. DeRogatis would team with Charlie Jones for the <a href="1968%20Boston%20Patriots%20season">Boston</a>-<a href="1968%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo</a> game on Saturday, and Gowdy and Rote would call the <a href="1968%20Kansas%20City%20Chiefs%20season">Kansas City</a>-<a href="1968%20Houston%20Oilers%20season">Houston</a> game on Sunday. The trio would also broadcast <a href="Super%20Bowl%20III">Super Bowl III</a>. Late in the season, there were a number of double-duty weeks by announcers. In Week 14, Jim Simpson and DeRogatis called the Buffalo-Houston game on Saturday, then the following day Simpson called the <a href="1968%20Denver%20Broncos%20season">Denver</a>-<a href="1968%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland</a> game while DeRogatis called the Cincinnati-<a href="1968%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">New York Jets</a> game. The following week, DeRogatis again pulled double-duty, calling the Kansas City-Denver game on Saturday (with Charlie Jones), then joining Jim Simpson for the Oakland-San Diego game the next day. Jones called the Boston-Houston game with <a href="George%20Ratterman">George Ratterman</a> also that week. Al DeRogatis called "<a href="The%20Heidi%20Game">The Heidi Game</a>" with Curt Gowdy in Week 11 (Rote joined Jim Simpson for the San Diego-Buffalo game). Charlie Jones substituted for Gowdy in Week 5 (Boston-Oakland), while Gowdy called Game 4 of the <a href="1968%20World%20Series">1968 World Series</a>.
The next three AFL-NFL World Championship Games, later renamed the "<a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a>", were then divided by the two networks (with each network broadcasting the game exclusively): CBS broadcast Super Bowls <a href="Super%20Bowl%20II">II</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20IV">IV</a> while NBC covered <a href="Super%20Bowl%20III">III</a>. When NBC Sports broadcast Super Bowl III, sports broadcasts were produced under the oversight of the <a href="NBC%20News">NBC News</a> division (this remained the case until 1978, long after both CBS and <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> had spun off their sports operations into departments separate from their news divisions). Curt Gowdy handled the play-by-play duties and was joined by <a href="color%20commentator">color commentator</a>s <a href="Al%20DeRogatis">Al DeRogatis</a> and <a href="Kyle%20Rote">Kyle Rote</a> in the broadcast booth. Also helping with NBC's coverage were <a href="Jim%20Simpson%20%28sportscaster%29">Jim Simpson</a> (reporting from the sidelines) and <a href="Pat%20Summerall">Pat Summerall</a> (helping conduct player interviews for the pregame show, along with Rote). In an interview later conducted with <a href="NFL%20Films">NFL Films</a>, Gowdy called it the most memorable game he ever called because of its historical significance. While the Orange Bowl was sold out for the game, the live telecast was not shown in Miami due to both leagues' unconditional <a href="blackout%20%28broadcasting%29">blackout</a> rules at the time. This game is thought to be the earliest surviving Super Bowl game preserved on videotape in its entirety save for a portion of the <a href="1968%20Baltimore%20Colts%20season">Baltimore Colts</a>' fourth-quarter scoring drive.
Charlie Jones substituted for Curt Gowdy during Week 5 of the <a href="American%20Football%20League%20seasons%231969">1969 season</a> (<a href="1969%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">New York Jets</a>-<a href="1969%20Cincinnati%20Bengals%20season">Cincinnati</a>), while Gowdy called Game 2 of the <a href="1969%20World%20Series">World Series</a>. Al DeRogatis substituted for Kyle Rote in Weeks 9 (San Diego-Kansas City) and 11 (<a href="1969%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland</a>-<a href="1969%20Kansas%20City%20Chiefs%20season">Kansas City</a>). Rote paired with Jim Simpson in both instances. And with 1969 being the final AFL season before the <a href="AFL%E2%80%93NFL%20merger">AFL–NFL merger</a>, this was also the final season where both leagues would have <a href="NFL%20on%20Thanksgiving%20Day">Thanksgiving</a> <a href="Doubleheader%20%28television%29">doubleheaders</a>. Starting in <a href="1970%20NFL%20season">1970</a>, only two games would be played on Thanksgiving, with the <a href="1970%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Lions</a> and <a href="1970%20Dallas%20Cowboys%20season">Cowboys</a> hosting those games, and an AFC team rotating as the visiting team between Detroit and Dallas every year.
"The Heidi Game".
One of the most remembered games on NBC was a <a href="American%20Football%20League%20seasons%231968">1968</a> game known as the "<a href="Heidi%20Game">Heidi Game</a>". As its nationally televised game between the <a href="1968%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland Raiders</a> and <a href="1968%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">New York Jets</a> running late, the network discontinued coverage while the game was still playing to air the movie "<a href="Heidi%20%281968%20film%29">Heidi</a>" just moments after the Jets' <a href="Jim%20Turner%20%28placekicker%29">Jim Turner</a> kicked what appeared to be the game-winning field goal with 1:05 remaining. While millions of irate fans, missing the finale, jammed NBC's phone lines, the Raiders scored two touchdowns in eight seconds during the final minute to win 43–32.
The reaction to "The Heidi Game" resulted in the AFL, and most other sports leagues, demanding thereafter that television networks broadcast all games to their conclusion. NFL contracts with the networks now require games to be shown in a team's market area to conclusion, regardless of the score.
To avoid a repeat incident, a 1975 NBC broadcast of "<a href="Willy%20Wonka%20%26amp%3B%20the%20Chocolate%20Factory">Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory</a>" was delayed until the completion of a <a href="1975%20Washington%20Redskins%20season">Washington Redskins</a>–<a href="1975%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Raiders</a> game. The network installed a new phone in the control room wired to a separate exchange, becoming known as the "Heidi Phone", to prevent this situation from occurring in the future.
1970s.
In <a href="1970%20NFL%20season">1970</a>, after the NFL and AFL completed their merger, NBC signed a contract with the league to broadcast games from the <a href="American%20Football%20Conference">American Football Conference</a> (AFC). After this season, Al DeRogatis and Kyle Rote swapped positions; resulting in DeRogatis being the #1 color commentator alongside Curt Gowdy and Rote being the #2 analyst alongside Jim Simpson.
On January 17, 1971, NBC's telecast of <a href="Super%20Bowl%20V">Super Bowl V</a> between the <a href="1970%20Baltimore%20Colts%20season">Baltimore Colts</a> and <a href="1970%20Dallas%20Cowboys%20season">Dallas Cowboys</a> was viewed in an estimated 23,980,000 homes, the largest household audience ever for a one-day sports event. The game was called by play-by-play announcer Gowdy and color commentator Rote. Although the <a href="Orange%20Bowl">Orange Bowl</a> was sold out for the event, unconditional blackout rules in the NFL prohibited the live telecast from being shown in the <a href="Miami">Miami</a> area on <a href="WSVN">WCKT</a>. The blackout was challenged in Miami-Dade District Court by attorney <a href="Ellis%20Rubin">Ellis Rubin</a>, and although the judge denied Rubin's request since he felt he did not have the power to overrule the NFL, he agreed with Rubin's argument that the blackout rule was unnecessary for the Super Bowl.
On Christmas Day, December 25, 1971, NBC telecast the AFC Divisional Playoff between the Kansas City Chiefs and Miami Dolphins. The contest, the final Chiefs game ever played in Kansas City's Municipal Stadium, started around 3 p.m. Central Time. The game lasted well into the evening, delaying some Christmas dinners around the country as the contest became the longest-running game in NFL history, lasting 80:22 of game time. In the second overtime period, Miami converted a field goal to win the thrilling contest, 27-24. Curt Gowdy and Al DeRogatis called the memorable game for NBC.
On January 14, 1973, NBC's telecast of <a href="Super%20Bowl%20VII">Super Bowl VII</a> between the <a href="1972%20Miami%20Dolphins%20season">Miami Dolphins</a> and <a href="1972%20Washington%20Redskins%20season">Washington Redskins</a> was watched by approximately 75 million viewers. NBC's telecast of <a href="Super%20Bowl%20IX">Super Bowl IX</a> between the <a href="1974%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> and <a href="1974%20Minnesota%20Vikings%20season">Minnesota Vikings</a> had an audience of approximately 78 million viewers. The 1973 game, called by Curt Gowdy and Al DeRogatis, was the first Super Bowl to be televised live in the city where it was being played. Despite the league's unconditional blackout rules that normally would have prohibited the live telecast from being shown locally, the NFL allowed the game to be telecast in the Los Angeles area on <a href="KNBC">KNBC</a> on an experimental basis when all tickets for the game were sold. The league then changed its blackout rules the following season to allow games sold out at least 72 hours in advance to be televised in the host market. No subsequent Super Bowl has ever been blacked out in the city it has been played in, since all of them have been sold out.
On December 16, <a href="1973%20NFL%20season">1973</a>, NBC cameras were there to cover <a href="O.%20J.%20Simpson">O. J. Simpson</a> as he rushed for 2,000 yards in one season. On that particular day, Simpson's <a href="1973%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo Bills</a> would go on to beat the <a href="1973%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">New York Jets</a> at <a href="Shea%20Stadium">Shea Stadium</a>. Two days before he was assigned to call 1973's regular-season finale between the <a href="1973%20Houston%20Oilers%20season">Houston Oilers</a> and <a href="1973%20Cincinnati%20Bengals%20season">Cincinnati Bengals</a>, <a href="Bill%20Enis">Bill Enis</a> died from a <a href="Myocardial%20infarction">heart attack</a> at the age of 39. <a href="Al%20Michaels">Al Michaels</a> was brought in to replace Enis in the booth with <a href="Dave%20Kocourek">Dave Kocourek</a>. <a href="1974%20NFL%20season">1974</a> would mark the final season for what would be Al Michaels' first stint with NBC. That season, Michaels called six-tier games with <a href="Mike%20Haffner">Mike Haffner</a>. Also in 1974, <a href="Don%20Meredith">Don Meredith</a> would come over to NBC from <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>'s "<a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">Monday Night Football</a>". He would join Curt Gowdy and Al DeRogatis for the <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20NFL%20playoffs">playoffs</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20IX">Super Bowl IX</a>. He also worked that year's Thanksgiving game between <a href="1974%20Denver%20Broncos%20season">Denver</a> and <a href="1974%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Detroit</a>. In Week 13, he joined Jim Simpson and <a href="John%20Brodie">John Brodie</a> to call the <a href="1974%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">Cleveland</a>-<a href="1974%20Dallas%20Cowboys%20season">Dallas</a> game.
In <a href="1975%20NFL%20season">1975</a>, because of NBC's coverage of Game 2 of the <a href="1975%20World%20Series">World Series</a> between the <a href="1975%20Cincinnati%20Reds%20season">Cincinnati Reds</a> and <a href="1975%20Boston%20Red%20Sox%20season">Boston Red Sox</a>, NBC's 1:00 p.m. NFL telecasts were canceled. All games except for the <a href="1975%20New%20England%20Patriots%20season">New England Patriots</a>–<a href="1975%20Cincinnati%20Bengals%20season">Cincinnati Bengals</a> match were picked up by local stations in the markets of the visiting team. Meanwhile, at 4:00 p.m. <a href="Eastern%20Time%20Zone">Eastern Time</a>, NBC aired a game between the <a href="1975%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland Raiders</a> and <a href="1975%20Kansas%20City%20Chiefs%20season">Kansas City Chiefs</a> nationally. As the 1975 World Series progressed, NBC would advertise its upcoming weekend schedule during the breaks:
As it turned out, no baseball was played that Sunday. Three days of rain in <a href="Boston">Boston</a> forced Game 6 to be postponed until the following Tuesday, October 21, followed by Game 7 the next night.
1975 was also the final season for Al DeRogatis at NBC. He would return briefly in <a href="1988%20NFL%20season">1988</a> as a fill-in color commentator during the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympics</a>. The <a href="1976%20NFL%20season">following year</a>, Curt Gowdy split double-duty with John Brodie and Don Meredith in Weeks 12 and 14. In Week 12, Gowdy and Brodie worked the Thanksgiving Day game (<a href="1976%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo</a>-<a href="1976%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Detroit</a>), while Gowdy and Meredith worked the <a href="1976%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">Pittsburgh</a>-<a href="1976%20Cincinnati%20Bengals%20season">Cincinnati</a> game. In Week 14, Gowdy and Brodie called the Pittsburgh-<a href="1976%20Houston%20Oilers%20season">Houston</a> game on Saturday, then the following day Gowdy and Meredith called the Cincinnati-<a href="1976%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">New York Jets</a> game. Don Meredith would return to ABC's "Monday Night Football" at the end of the season. After Meredith left NBC, John Brodie would be the top color commentator alongside Curt Gowdy in <a href="1977%20NFL%20season">1977</a> and <a href="1978%20NFL%20season">1978</a>. Meanwhile, after this season, <a href="Tim%20Ryan%20%28sportscaster%29">Tim Ryan</a>, who was on the fifth-tier announcing team with <a href="Lionel%20Aldridge">Lionel Aldridge</a>, left NBC to join <a href="CBS%20Sports">CBS Sports</a>.
On January 9, 1977, 81.9 million people (the largest audience ever for a sporting event at that point) watched NBC's telecast of <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XI">Super Bowl XI</a> between the <a href="1976%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland Raiders</a> and <a href="1976%20Minnesota%20Vikings%20season">Minnesota Vikings</a>. Only three other television events prior to that time, all of which aired on all three commercial networks of the era (the funeral of President <a href="John%20F.%20Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a>, the 1969 moonwalk of <a href="Neil%20Armstrong">Neil Armstrong</a> and <a href="Buzz%20Aldrin">Buzz Aldrin</a>, and the 1974 resignation speech of President <a href="Richard%20M.%20Nixon">Richard M. Nixon</a>), attracted more viewers than Super Bowl IX. The game was also the last broadcast that color commentator Don Meredith, who called the game with Gowdy, did for NBC, as he returned to ABC to rejoin the "<a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">Monday Night Football</a>" crew for the <a href="1977%20NFL%20season">1977 season</a>, where he had been a commentator from 1970 to 1973. <a href="Bryant%20Gumbel">Bryant Gumbel</a> and <a href="Lee%20Leonard">Lee Leonard</a> with analyst <a href="John%20Brodie">John Brodie</a> anchored NBC's pregame, halftime and postgame coverage.
On October 12, 1977, Commissioner <a href="Pete%20Rozelle">Pete Rozelle</a> negotiated contracts with the three television networks to televise all NFL regular season and postseason games, as well as select preseason games, for four years beginning with the <a href="1978%20NFL%20season">1978 season</a>. <a href="ESPN%20on%20ABC">ABC</a> was awarded yearly rights to 16 <a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">Monday night games</a>, four <a href="prime%20time">prime time</a> games, the <a href="Pro%20Bowl">AFC-NFC Pro Bowl</a>, and the <a href="Pro%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20Game">Hall of Fame Games</a>. <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a> received the rights to all <a href="National%20Football%20Conference">National Football Conference</a> (NFC) regular season and postseason games (except those in the ABC package) and to Super Bowls <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XIV">XIV</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XVI">XVI</a>. NBC received the rights to all AFC regular-season and postseason games (again, except those in the ABC package) and to Super Bowls <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XIII">XIII</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XV">XV</a>. Industry sources considered it the largest single television package ever negotiated.
After the <a href="1977%20NFL%20season">1977 season</a>, <a href="Jack%20Buck">Jack Buck</a>, who was the initial host for <a href="The%20NFL%20on%20NBC%20pregame%20show%23GrandStand%20%281975%E2%80%931976%29">NBC's first official studio pregame show</a> in <a href="1975%20NFL%20season">1975</a>, and on the fourth-tier announcing crew with <a href="Jimmy%20Johnson%20%28cornerback%29">Jimmy Johnson</a> in 1977, would return to CBS Sports, primarily calling games for <a href="NFL%20on%20Westwood%20One%20Sports">CBS Radio</a>. Dick Stockton, who was on the sixth-tier team with Len Dawson, would also return to CBS Sports.
The end of the Curt Gowdy era.
After the <a href="1975%20World%20Series">1975 World Series</a>, Curt Gowdy was removed from NBC's baseball telecasts, when sponsor <a href="Chrysler">Chrysler</a> insisted on having <a href="Joe%20Garagiola%20Sr.">Joe Garagiola</a> (who served as a spokesman in many of the automotive manufacturer's commercials) be the lead play-by-play voice. Gowdy continued as NBC's lead NFL announcer through the <a href="1978%20NFL%20season">1978 season</a>, with his final broadcast being the memorable <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XIII">Super Bowl XIII</a> between the <a href="1978%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> and <a href="1978%20Dallas%20Cowboys%20season">Dallas Cowboys</a>. With NBC now anxious to promote <a href="Dick%20Enberg">Dick Enberg</a> (who hosted NBC's pre-game and post-game coverage of Super Bowl XIII) to the lead NFL position, Gowdy moved over to <a href="CBS%20Sports">CBS</a> to call more <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">football</a>, as well as <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20CBS%20Radio">baseball on radio</a>.
The teams of Dick Enberg and Merlin Olsen and Curt Gowdy and John Brodie began 1978 as co-head crews. But the unofficial passing of the torch happened on Thanksgiving, when Enberg and Olsen covered the <a href="1978%20Denver%20Broncos%20season">Denver</a>-<a href="1978%20Detroit%20Lions%20season">Detroit</a> game, while the following Sunday, Gowdy and Brodie covered the <a href="1978%20Seattle%20Seahawks%20season">Seattle</a>-<a href="1978%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland</a> game. Len Dawson joined Dick Enberg in covering the <a href="1978%20Houston%20Oilers%20season">Houston</a>-<a href="1978%20Miami%20Dolphins%20season">Miami</a> <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20NFL%20playoffs%23Wild%20Card%20playoffs">wild card game</a>, and Charlie Jones in the Houston-<a href="1978%20New%20England%20Patriots%20season">New England</a> divisional playoff game. Dawson did not work Week 15 due to mourning the death of his wife. Merlin Olsen would join Curt Gowdy and John Brodie for that season's AFC Championship Game.
NBC's January 21, 1979 telecast of <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XIII">Super Bowl XIII</a> between the Pittsburgh Steelers and Dallas Cowboys was viewed in 35,090,000 households, by an estimated 96.6 million fans. The game – called by Curt Gowdy on play-by-play, with Merlin Olsen and John Brodie on color commentary and Dick Enberg serving as the pregame host for the broadcast with <a href="Bryant%20Gumbel">Bryant Gumbel</a> and <a href="Mike%20Adamle">Mike Adamle</a> as sideline reporters – was Gowdy's seventh and final Super Bowl telecast, and his last major event for NBC before moving to CBS later in 1979. Enberg had essentially succeeded Gowdy as NBC's lead NFL play-by-play announcer in the 1978 regular season, and network producers did not decide until nearly the last minute which of them would conduct play-by-play for that year's Super Bowl. NBC preceded the game with the first network broadcast of "<a href="Black%20Sunday%20%281977%20film%29">Black Sunday</a>", a 1977 film that depicts a terrorist attack on a fictitious Super Bowl game in the Orange Bowl between Pittsburgh and Dallas (and which utilized footage shot during Super Bowl X). The pregame festivities featured the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys%20Cheerleaders">Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders</a> and several military bands. <a href="The%20Colgate%20Thirteen">The Colgate Thirteen</a> performed the national anthem. The <a href="coin%20flipping">coin toss</a> ceremony featured <a href="Pro%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Pro Football Hall of Fame</a>r and longtime <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a> owner/head coach <a href="George%20Halas">George Halas</a>. The national radio broadcast of Super Bowl XIII was carried by the <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS%20Radio">CBS Radio</a> Network, with <a href="Jack%20Buck">Jack Buck</a> and <a href="Hank%20Stram">Hank Stram</a> calling the action. Locally on radio, <a href="Verne%20Lundquist">Verne Lundquist</a> and <a href="Brad%20Sham">Brad Sham</a> called the game for the Cowboys on <a href="KRLD%20%28AM%29">KRLD</a> in <a href="Dallas">Dallas</a>, while <a href="Jack%20Fleming">Jack Fleming</a> and <a href="Myron%20Cope">Myron Cope</a> called it for the Steelers on <a href="WPGP%20%28AM%29">WTAE</a> in Pittsburgh. A technical glitch led to Fleming and Cope's commentary going out over NBC's television broadcast in place of the network's own audio during the coin toss ceremony.
After his call of Super Bowl XIII, Curt Gowdy would leave NBC for CBS, calling games with <a href="Hank%20Stram">Hank Stram</a> for two seasons.
1980s.
NBC made history in the 1980s with an <a href="Announcerless%20game">announcerless telecast</a>, which was a one-shot experiment credited to <a href="Don%20Ohlmeyer">Don Ohlmeyer</a>, between the <a href="1980%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">Jets</a> and <a href="1980%20Miami%20Dolphins%20season">Dolphins</a> in <a href="Miami%20Orange%20Bowl">Miami</a> on December 20, <a href="1980%20NFL%20season">1980</a>, as well as a single-announcer telecast, coverage of the <a href="1982%20CFL%20season">Canadian Football League</a> during the <a href="1982%20NFL%20season">1982</a> players' strike (the first week of broadcasts featured the "NFL on NBC" broadcast teams, before a series of blowout games on the network and the resulting low <a href="Nielsen%20ratings">ratings</a> resulted in NBC cutting back and eventually canceling its CFL coverage), and even the first female play-by-play football announcer, <a href="Gayle%20Sierens">Gayle Sierens</a> (which in its own way set the mold for female sportscasters of today).
<a href="Bob%20Trumpy">Bob Trumpy</a> filled in for Merlin Olsen alongside Dick Enberg during the <a href="1980%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland</a>-<a href="1980%20Philadelphia%20Eagles%20season">Philadelphia</a> regular season game in Week 12 of the <a href="1980%20NFL%20season">1980 season</a>.
<a href="Nielsen%20ratings">Television ratings</a> in 1980 were the second-best in NFL history, trailing only the combined ratings of the <a href="1976%20NFL%20season">1976 season</a>. All three networks posted gains, and NBC's 15.0 rating was its best ever. NFL broadcasts on CBS and ABC had their best ratings since 1977, with 15.3 and 20.8 ratings, respectively. In <a href="1981%20NFL%20season">1981</a>, ABC and CBS set all-time rating highs. ABC finished with a 21.7 rating and CBS with a 17.5 rating. NBC however, was down slightly to 13.9; this was, at the time, the nadir of the <a href="Fred%20Silverman">Fred Silverman</a> era, when ratings for the network were down across the board.
On November 15, 1981, the <a href="1981%20San%20Francisco%2049ers%20season">San Francisco 49ers</a> game against the <a href="1981%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">Cleveland Browns</a> sold out in time for the <a href="National%20Football%20League%20television%20blackout%20policies">TV blackout</a> to be lifted. But <a href="KRON-TV">KRON</a> (NBC in the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Bay%20Area">Bay Area</a>) had to air <a href="1981%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland</a>'s road game against <a href="1981%20Miami%20Dolphins%20season">Miami</a>. They ultimately showed the Browns-49ers game on <a href="Broadcast%20delay">tape delay</a> that night.
On January 2, 1982, NBC was on hand for a <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20NFL%20playoffs">divisional playoff game</a> between the <a href="1981%20San%20Diego%20Chargers%20season">San Diego Chargers</a> and <a href="1981%20Miami%20Dolphins%20season">Miami Dolphins</a> that would go down as the "<a href="Epic%20in%20Miami">Epic in Miami</a>". The game, won by the Chargers in overtime, 41–38, is one of the most famous in National Football League lore because of the conditions on the field, the performances of players on both teams, and the numerous records that were set. <a href="Don%20Criqui">Don Criqui</a> and <a href="John%20Brodie">John Brodie</a> called the action and <a href="Bryant%20Gumbel">Bryant Gumbel</a> served as the anchor, one of his final assignments for NBC Sports as he began co-hosting "<a href="Today%20%28U.S.%20TV%20program%29">Today</a>" two days after the game. The following week, NBC covered the AFC Championship Game between the Chargers and <a href="1981%20Cincinnati%20Bengals%20season">Cincinnati Bengals</a>. While the "Epic in Miami" was played in the heat and humidity of <a href="Miami">Miami</a>, the Chargers found themselves dealing with nearly the exact opposite conditions in the "<a href="Freezer%20Bowl">Freezer Bowl</a>" in <a href="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a>.
In 1982, the NFL signed a five-year contract with the three television networks (ABC, CBS, and NBC) to televise all NFL regular season and postseason games starting with the <a href="1982%20NFL%20season">1982 season</a>. During the 1982 season, Dick Enberg teamed with John Brodie to call the Week 1 game between the <a href="1982%20Los%20Angeles%20Raiders%20season">Raiders</a>-<a href="1982%20San%20Francisco%2049ers%20season">49ers</a>, and then with Len Dawson for the Week 2 game between the Raiders and <a href="1982%20Atlanta%20Falcons%20season">Falcons</a>.
NBC's national <a href="Nielsen%20rating">Nielsen rating</a> of 48.6 for <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XVII">Super Bowl XVII</a> was the second-highest for a Super Bowl broadcast, trailing only the 49.1 garnered by <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XVI">Super Bowl XVI</a> on CBS the year before. Following the game, NBC aired the premiere episode of "<a href="The%20A-Team">The A-Team</a>", beginning the tradition of the game's host network airing <a href="List%20of%20Super%20Bowl%20lead-out%20programs">programming after the game</a>.
On August 3, 1983, NBC broadcast the first televised NFL game from <a href="London">London</a> with the <a href="1983%20St.%20Louis%20Cardinals%20%28NFL%29%20season">St. Louis Cardinals</a> and <a href="1983%20Minnesota%20Vikings%20season">Minnesota Vikings</a> <a href="List%20of%20National%20Football%20League%20games%20played%20outside%20the%20United%20States">playing</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a>. NBC would regularly televise <a href="List%20of%20American%20Bowl%20broadcasters">pre-season exhibition games outside of the United States</a> from <a href="1986%20NFL%20season">1986</a>-<a href="1994%20NFL%20season">1994</a>. <a href="1983%20NFL%20season">1983</a> was also <a href="Bob%20Costas">Bob Costas</a>' last season in the booth (by this time, he was on the fourth-tier team with Bob Trumpy) before being promoted as the new host (replacing <a href="Len%20Berman">Len Berman</a>) of <a href="The%20NFL%20on%20NBC%20pregame%20show%23NFL%20%281977%E2%80%931986%29">"NFL '84"</a>.
In the <a href="1984%20NFL%20season">1984 season</a>, the October 18 game between the <a href="1984%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> at <a href="1984%20San%20Francisco%2049ers%20season">San Francisco 49ers</a> and the <a href="1984%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo Bills</a> at <a href="1984%20Seattle%20Seahawks%20season">Seattle Seahawks</a> were both on at the same time as Game 5 of the <a href="1984%20World%20Series">World Series</a> (also on <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20NBC">NBC</a>) between the <a href="1984%20San%20Diego%20Padres%20season">San Diego Padres</a> and the <a href="1984%20Detroit%20Tigers%20season">Detroit Tigers</a>. The Steelers won that day. It was the only loss the 49ers suffered in the 1984 season. Meanwhile, almost of the <a href="1984%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">New York Jets</a> games that year were called by <a href="Marv%20Albert">Marv Albert</a> and John Brodie also worked with Phil Stone (for the Steelers-<a href="1984%20Houston%20Oilers%20season">Oilers</a> game in Week 14), and <a href="Marty%20Glickman">Marty Glickman</a> (for the Bills-Jets in Week 15) in 1984, and <a href="Jay%20Randolph">Jay Randolph</a> (for the Steelers-<a href="1984%20Los%20Angeles%20Raiders%20season">Raiders</a> game in Week 16).
For the 1985 season, NBC used Graham De Wilde's composition "Send Them Victorious" for their official theme music for the NFL. On January 26, 1986, the <a href="1985%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">Chicago Bears</a> defeated the <a href="1985%20New%20England%20Patriots%20season">New England Patriots</a> 46–10 in <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XX">Super Bowl XX</a> at the <a href="Louisiana%20Superdome">Louisiana Superdome</a>. The NBC telecast replaced the <a href="Goodbye%2C%20Farewell%20and%20Amen">final episode</a> of "<a href="M%2AA%2AS%2AH%20%28TV%20series%29">M*A*S*H</a>" as the most-viewed television program in history, with an audience of 127 million viewers, according to ACNielsen figures. The announcerless and single-announcer games.
<a href="Don%20Ohlmeyer">Don Ohlmeyer</a>, then <a href="Television%20producer">executive producer</a> of <a href="NBC">NBC</a>'s telecasts of <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) games, began considering doing a telecast without announcers early in <a href="1980%20National%20Football%20League%20season">the 1980 season</a>. He had several reasons. First, he had long believed that the announcers were overly chatty and did not let the game speak for itself when they needed to. Second, NBC, while it primarily covered the games of the NFL's <a href="American%20Football%20Conference">American Football Conference</a> (AFC) teams, generally in smaller <a href="media%20market">markets</a>, was earning <a href="Nielsen%20ratings">ratings</a> almost as good as those of rival <a href="CBS">CBS</a>, who at the time was broadcasting games involving teams from the <a href="National%20Football%20Conference">National Football Conference</a> (NFC). A game without announcers might well attract enough viewers to put NBC past CBS.
In October of that year reports began to circulate that Ohlmeyer was considering the idea. He confirmed it but said he would only actually do it for a game that had no <a href="National%20Football%20League%20playoffs">playoff</a> implications. The last week of the season gave him the chance, with a contest scheduled for Saturday, when it would be shown nationally, between the <a href="New%20York%20Jets">New York Jets</a> and the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a>.
Reaction was mixed, ranging from "good-natured humor to applause to some surprising anger," as <a href="Bryant%20Gumbel">Bryant Gumbel</a> would later put it on air shortly before the telecast started. "My first reaction was of incredible nerve, nervousness," <a href="Dick%20Enberg">Dick Enberg</a>, one of the NBC announcers, recalled to <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> 30 years later. "We all gathered together, hoping that Ohlmeyer was dead wrong ... What if this crazy idea really worked?" Dolphins' <a href="defensive%20end">defensive end</a> <a href="Bob%20Baumhower">Bob Baumhower</a> was also apprehensive about what viewers might overhear among the players. "I hope we're all extra careful," he said. "There's a lot of extra talking going on out there that people don't realize."
Ohlmeyer and the NBC broadcast crew prepared to compensate for the lack of announcers in several ways. NBC promoted the game by telling viewers they would, in lieu of announcers, have the experience of actually being in the stadium, so the network placed more microphones, and more sensitive microphones, around the field than it otherwise would have. However, the NFL refused to relax one of its restrictions and allow microphones to be placed on the players themselves, which unfortunately meant that it was impossible for viewers to make out signals called by the quarterbacks.
The network increased its use of on-camera graphics during the game to regularly convey <a href="Down%20%28gridiron%20football%29">down</a> and distance, score, and statistical information, to the point that more were than had ever been used in any previous NFL telecast. The monochromatic yellow line that was superimposed on the field to indicate the distance needed for a first-down was then the most advanced technology available; however, speaking later from a 21st-century perspective, Ohlmeyer said seems like "<a href="Cave%20dweller">troglodyte</a> communication". The technology of the time would have allowed for a continuous <a href="score%20bug">score bug</a> and a running clock, both of which would have eliminated the need to constantly provide that information, but it did not occur to the crew to deploy it that way.
NBC asked Bob Kaufman, the Orange Bowl's <a href="public%20address%20system">public address</a> announcer, to make more frequent announcements of information than usual, and to include more information in those announcements than stadium announcers typically did. Accordingly, he noted aloud during the game that referees were calling for a first-down measurement, and Kaufman gave the length of game time that a <a href="drive%20%28American%20football%29">drive</a> had taken. Television audiences were able to hear this.
Bryant Gumbel introduced the game prior to the <a href="Kickoff%20%28gridiron%20football%29">kickoff</a> as "a telecast that figures to be different." He was then shown walking into the stadium to watch the game. At frequent intervals, usually every other commercial break, he addressed the camera and gave the audience the score and brief updates as to what had happened and what was happening at that point. His presence was augmented by excerpts from prerecorded interviews with coaches and players, including the Dolphins' <a href="Don%20Shula">Don Shula</a> and <a href="Duriel%20Harris">Duriel Harris</a>.

On March 12, 1990, at the NFL's annual meeting in <a href="Orlando%2C%20Florida">Orlando, Florida</a>, the league new ratified four-year television agreements for the <a href="1990%20NFL%20season">1990</a> to <a href="1993%20NFL%20season">1993 seasons</a> involving ABC, CBS, NBC, <a href="ESPN%20Sunday%20Night%20Football">ESPN</a> and <a href="TNT%20Sunday%20Night%20Football">TNT</a>. The contracts totaled US$3.6 billion, the largest package in television history. This contract saw each network having rights to one Super Bowl telecast as part of the package. The fourth Super Bowl (<a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXVIII">XXVIII</a>) was up for a separate sealed bid. NBC won the bid, and since they were last in the rotation for Super Bowl coverage in the regular contract, ended up with two straight Super Bowls (although they were originally scheduled to broadcast <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXVI">Super Bowl XXVI</a>; CBS instead televised the game as part of a swap with the network). CBS is the only other network to televise two Super Bowls (Super Bowl I and II) in a row. NBC, which had held XXVII (according to the original rotation, NBC would have had XXVI and CBS XXVII, but the NFL allowed the networks to switch the two games in order to allow CBS a significant lead-in to its coverage of the <a href="1992%20Winter%20Olympics">1992 Winter Olympics</a>), was the only network to bid on XXVIII. Previously, the league alternated the Super Bowl broadcast among its broadcast network partners, except for Super Bowl I; CBS broadcast Super Bowl II, then the league rotated the broadcast between CBS and NBC until 1985 when ABC entered the rotation when that network broadcast <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XIX">Super Bowl XIX</a>.
The live Sunday matches of the <a href="1991%20Ryder%20Cup">1991 Ryder Cup</a> held in late September on <a href="Golf%20Channel%20on%20NBC">NBC</a> were scheduled to end by mid-afternoon in order to allow NBC to cover regional NFL games at 4:00 p.m. Eastern Time.
Dick Enberg and Bill Walsh did not call any games during Weeks 9-12 of the <a href="1991%20NFL%20season">1991 NFL season</a> due to being assigned to covering <a href="1991%20Notre%20Dame%20Fighting%20Irish%20football%20team">Notre Dame</a> home games on <a href="Notre%20Dame%20Football%20on%20NBC">NBC</a> (this being the network's first season as the home of Fighting Irish home games). Walsh would leave NBC after this season to return to coaching at <a href="1992%20Stanford%20Cardinal%20football%20team">Stanford</a>. Walsh's spot as NBC's number #1 color commentator would be subsequently filled by Bob Trumpy. Meanwhile, <a href="Bill%20Parcells">Bill Parcells</a> was originally hired by NBC after leaving the New York Giants as a panelist for "NFL Live!". However, he would be assigned early in the 1991 season as a substitute for Paul Maguire while Maguire recovered from a <a href="Myocardial%20infarction">heart attack</a>. Maguire would make his return in Week 6, calling the <a href="1991%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">Jets</a>-<a href="1991%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">Browns</a> game alongside Marv Albert. Bill Parcells left NBC the 1992 season to take the <a href="1993%20New%20England%20Patriots%20season">New England Patriots</a> head coaching job. Simpson, play-by-play broadcaster <a href="Tom%20Hammond">Tom Hammond</a> and analyst <a href="Todd%20Christensen">Todd Christensen</a> were assigned to cover the <a href="1991%20World%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">world track and field championships</a> in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. The NFL completed its new television agreements on December 20, with the announcement that NBC would retain the rights to the AFC package.

On December 17, 1995, NBC was on hand for the final home game for the <a href="1995%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">Cleveland Browns</a> before their <a href="Cleveland%20Browns%20relocation%20controversy">relocation</a> to <a href="1996%20Baltimore%20Ravens%20season">Baltimore</a>. Experimenting with three-man booths.
Following Week 3 of the <a href="1997%20NFL%20season">1997 season</a>, Marv Albert was fired by NBC because of <a href="Marv%20Albert%23Sexual%20assault">sexual assault charges</a> pressed against him. Albert, also the lead voice of "<a href="NBA%20on%20NBC">NBA on NBC</a>" at the time, was replaced in both venues.
