Revisiting the "Immaculate Reception".
In 1998, during halftime of the , NBC showed a replay of the "<a href="Immaculate%20Reception">Immaculate Reception</a>" from its original broadcast of the <a href="1972%20NFL%20season">1972</a> <a href="American%20Football%20Conference">AFC</a> between <a href="1972%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> and <a href="1972%20Oakland%20Raiders%20season">Oakland Raiders</a>. The replay presented a different angle than the <a href="NFL%20Films">NFL Films</a> clip that is most often shown. According to a writer for the "<a href="New%20York%20Daily%20News">New York Daily News</a>", "NBC's replay showed the ball clearly hit one and only one man[:] Oakland DB <a href="Jack%20Tatum">Jack Tatum</a>." <a href="Curt%20Gowdy">Curt Gowdy</a>, doing the live TV play-by-play, called it as having been deflected by Tatum, and reiterated that during the video replay.
NBC loses the rights to CBS.
NBC's rebound in overall ratings in both the 1980s and 1990s (after years of being in the bottom of the ratings cellar) was attributed in part to its continuing coverage of the NFL. But with television contract re-negotiations in early 1998 ushering in the era of multibillion-dollar broadcasting agreements, an era of pro football broadcasting would soon come to an unceremonious conclusion.
As previously mentioned, CBS, stung by Fox's surprise bid <a href="1994%20NFL%20season">four years earlier</a>, aggressively pursued NFL broadcast rights when the contract came up for renegotiation in 1997. CBS agreed to pay US$4 billion over eight years ($500 million per season) to take over NBC's AFC broadcast rights, which the network still holds to this day. NBC, meanwhile, had indicated a desire to bid for "<a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">Monday Night Football</a>" rights in <a href="1998%20NFL%20season">1998</a>, but eventually gave up, allowing ABC to retain the rights.
NBC's consecutive 33-year run as a football broadcaster came to an end with <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXII">Super Bowl XXXII</a>, played on January 25, 1998 between the <a href="1997%20Denver%20Broncos%20season">Denver Broncos</a> and the <a href="1997%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">Green Bay Packers</a>. The Broncos won 31–24 to snap the AFC's 13-year losing streak in the Super Bowl (since then, the AFC has won eleven additional Super Bowls to the NFC's seven). Following the game, NBC aired a special one-hour episode of "<a href="3rd%20Rock%20from%20the%20Sun">3rd Rock from the Sun</a>", which opened live at the game site with Greg Gumbel playing himself before he was "attacked" by show star <a href="John%20Lithgow">John Lithgow</a> as his Dick Solomon character, warning about the invasion of alien females that was part of the episode's plotline.
While at CBS, Randy Cross would become the #2 analyst, <a href="Sam%20Wyche">Sam Wyche</a> would leave the pregame show to become the #3 analyst, and Don Criqui and Beasley Reece would reunite for the <a href="1998%20NFL%20season">1998 season</a>. Dick Enberg would stay with NBC for another two years before joining CBS in <a href="2000%20NFL%20season">2000</a>, where he would be the #2 announcer until <a href="2005%20NFL%20season">2005</a>. Cris Collinsworth joined "<a href="Fox%20NFL%20Sunday">Fox NFL Sunday</a>" and then would team up with <a href="Joe%20Buck">Joe Buck</a> and <a href="Troy%20Aikman">Troy Aikman</a> on the #1 team from <a href="2002%20NFL%20season">2002</a>-<a href="2004%20NFL%20season">2004</a>.
Given the challenge of making its coverage of the American Football Conference different from that of NBC, CBS passed over longtime NBC veterans Charlie Jones and Bob Trumpy in favor of newcomers such as <a href="Ian%20Eagle">Ian Eagle</a> and <a href="Steve%20Tasker">Steve Tasker</a>. According to CBS Sports <a href="executive%20producer">executive producer</a> Terry Ewert, "We wanted to forge our own way and go in a different direction. We wanted to make decisions on a new way of looking at things." In one stark difference from NBC, CBS used a <a href="Digital%20on-screen%20graphic">score and clock graphic</a> for its NFL games that was constant during the game broadcasts outside of break tosses, a la the "<a href="FoxBox%20%28sports%29">FoxBox</a>". CBS' contribution was dubbed the "<a href="EyeBox">EyeBox</a>".
2000s.
After NBC lost its NFL rights to CBS at the end of the <a href="1997%20NFL%20season">1997 season</a>, it in the process, marked the beginning of a slow decline for its sports division, culminating in the unproductive <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20United%20States%20network%20television%20schedule">2004–05 prime time season</a> (despite heavy lineup promotion during the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a>), when NBC carried no major sporting championships during prime time (NBC had already lost <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20NBC">Major League Baseball</a> broadcasting rights in <a href="2000%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20season">2000</a> and <a href="NBA%20on%20NBC">National Basketball Association</a> rights in <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20NBA%20season">2002</a>; the network had acquired <a href="NHL%20on%20NBC">National Hockey League</a> rights in 2004, but that league was involved in a <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20NHL%20lockout">lockout</a> that cancelled the <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20NHL%20season">season</a>). The other major sport on NBC was <a href="NASCAR%20on%20NBC">the NASCAR Winston/Nextel Cup Series</a>.
NBC's attempts to replace the NFL with other professional football, including the <a href="XFL%20%282001%29">XFL</a> in 2001 and the <a href="AFL%20on%20NBC">Arena Football League coverage</a> from <a href="2003%20Arena%20Football%20League%20season">2003</a> to <a href="2006%20Arena%20Football%20League%20season">2006</a>, proved to be very unsuccessful. Like CBS before it, NBC would later decide that not having NFL rights did too much damage to its overall ratings to justify foregoing the high rights fees required.
In <a href="2005%20NFL%20season">2005</a>, NBC re-entered the NFL picture during negotiations for television contracts. The network was able to take advantage of a league desire to be able to switch the schedule so non-competitive games would not air in the league's marquee timeslot. Since this would require a move to Sunday night in order for this to happen, and since ABC decided to relinquish their rights to "Monday Night Football", NBC was able to bid on the "Sunday Night Football" package and won the rights after ESPN (corporate sibling to ABC and which had previously held those rights) elected to take over the "Monday Night Football" rights from ABC. NBC resumed airing NFL football on August 6, <a href="2006%20NFL%20season">2006</a>, with coverage of the annual <a href="AFC-NFC%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20Game">AFC-NFC Hall of Fame Game</a>.
NBC's rights package is nearly identical to the previous ABC package; in addition to the Hall of Fame Game, the contract gave NBC the rights to one additional preseason game, the <a href="National%20Football%20League%20Kickoff%20game">National Football League Kickoff game</a>, and two Saturday playoff games. NBC also received the rights to two Super Bowls in its bidding, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIII">Super Bowl XLIII</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLVI">Super Bowl XLVI</a> as well as the Pro Bowls in each of those two years. ABC did not have the right to be flexible with their "Monday Night Football" schedule and picked matchups based on a team's record in the previous season (as NBC does), which often led to teams with losing records playing each other on Monday night later in the season. The moves were intended to break NBC out of its ratings slump; however, this did not happen right away, and although "NBC Sunday Night Football" is the network's top-rated program and places in the top 30 among all broadcast network programs, it had no effect on the rest of the network's schedule for several years.
<a href="Al%20Michaels">Al Michaels</a>, the longtime voice of "Monday Night Football" and other events for ABC, moved to NBC to become the play-by-play announcer for "Sunday Night Football". Michaels was originally slated to continue calling "Monday Night Football" for ESPN, but a trade was worked out between NBC and <a href="The%20Walt%20Disney%20Company">The Walt Disney Company</a>, the parent company of ABC and ESPN. In the trade, Michaels was able to join NBC in exchange for Disney acquiring from NBC's corporate sibling <a href="Universal%20Pictures">Universal Pictures</a>, among other things, the rights to the cartoon character <a href="Oswald%20the%20Lucky%20Rabbit">Oswald the Lucky Rabbit</a>, which was created at Universal by <a href="Walt%20Disney">Walt Disney</a> and <a href="Ub%20Iwerks">Ub Iwerks</a> before the founding of Disney's studio (and then given to <a href="Walter%20Lantz">Walter Lantz</a>, whose most famous creation would be <a href="Woody%20Woodpecker">Woody Woodpecker</a>).
Except in <a href="2007%20NFL%20season">2007</a> (where the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game was televised by <a href="NFL%20Network">NFL Network</a> as part of the "<a href="Thursday%20Night%20Football">Thursday Night Football</a>" package; NBC had intended to televise the <a href="China%20Bowl%20%28NFL%29">China Bowl</a> game in <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>, which was postponed and ultimately cancelled), and in all <a href="Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympics</a> years (due to <a href="NBC%20Olympic%20broadcasts">NBC's telecasts of the Games</a>; the games in these years have typically been assigned to either NFL Network, or <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> under the current iteration of "MNF"), the Hall of Fame Game has aired on NBC since 2006.
<a href="John%20Madden">John Madden</a> (who had last worked with Al Michaels on "Monday Night Football" for ABC) was one of the first people hired by NBC, chosen to continue as a color analyst. <a href="Cris%20Collinsworth">Cris Collinsworth</a> substituted for Madden when he was unavailable. For example, during Week 7 of the <a href="2008%20NFL%20season">2008 season</a> (that week's game was involved the <a href="2008%20Seattle%20Seahawks%20season">Seattle Seahawks</a> playing against the <a href="2008%20Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers%20season">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a>), Madden was given an off-week to alleviate a hectic coast-to-coast bus travel schedule which would have taken him from <a href="2008%20Jacksonville%20Jaguars%20season">Jacksonville</a> to <a href="2008%20San%20Diego%20Chargers%20season">San Diego</a> to Tampa Bay in three weeks.
NBC broadcasts their first Super Bowl in 11 years.
<a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIII">Super Bowl XLIII</a> was NBC's first Super Bowl broadcast since Super Bowl XXXII, The five-hour pre-game show was preceded by a two-hour special edition of "<a href="Today%20%28U.S.%20TV%20program%29">Today</a>" hosted by the regular weekday team live from Tampa and the <a href="NFL%20Films">NFL Films</a> – produced "Road to the Super Bowl". <a href="Matt%20Millen">Matt Millen</a> was part of the coverage as a studio analyst. The "Today" contribution included portions of a taped interview with <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> and pictures of troops viewing the proceedings in <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>. His calling of the game made John Madden (in his final game broadcast) the first person to have announced a Super Bowl for each of the four major U.S. television networks, having called five Super Bowls for CBS, three for <a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox</a>, and two for ABC prior to joining NBC in 2006; Al Michaels also became the second person (after <a href="Pat%20Summerall">Pat Summerall</a> on <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a> and <a href="Fox%20NFL">Fox</a>) to be the lead Super Bowl play-by-play announcer for two different major U.S. networks (ABC and NBC). The Super Bowl was one of two major professional sports championship series <a href="NBC%20Sports">NBC</a> broadcast in 2009, as it would also broadcast the <a href="2009%20Stanley%20Cup%20Finals">Stanley Cup Finals</a>. Both championship series involved teams from Pittsburgh winning championships (the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Pittsburgh%20Penguins%20season">Penguins</a> would win the Stanley Cup that year).
The NFL has a strict policy prohibiting networks to run ads during the Super Bowl from the gambling industry, and has rejected ads from the <a href="Las%20Vegas%20Convention%20and%20Visitors%20Authority">Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority</a>. It had been reported that if the television program "<a href="Las%20Vegas%20%28TV%20series%29">Las Vegas</a>" was airing when NBC televised <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIII">Super Bowl XLIII</a> in 2009, they likely would not have been allowed to promote the series during the entire broadcast. As "Vegas" ended during the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20United%20States%20network%20television%20schedule">2007–2008 television season</a>, this was no longer an issue for NBC.
With an average U.S. audience of 98.7 million viewers, Super Bowl XLIII was the most-watched Super Bowl in history, and at that point the second-most-watched U.S. television program of any kind (trailing only the final episode of "<a href="M%2AA%2AS%2AH%20%28TV%20series%29">M*A*S*H</a>" in 1983; both would be broken by <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIV">Super Bowl XLIV</a> the following year). However, the Nielsen rating of 42.1, was lower than the 43.3 rating for Super Bowl XLII the previous year.
Wild Card Weekend coverage.
<a href="Tom%20Hammond">Tom Hammond</a> was initially NBC's secondary play-by-play announcer, calling one of NBC's two games on <a href="Wild%20card%20%28sports%29%23Football">Wild Card Weekend</a>. Cris Collinsworth called wild card games alongside Hammond until <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20NFL%20playoffs%23Wild%20Card%20playoffs">2008</a>, and took over on a permanent basis for the <a href="2009%20NFL%20season">2009 season</a> when Madden announced his retirement from broadcasting on April 16, 2009. Prior to this, he served as a studio analyst for NBC's pregame show, "<a href="Football%20Night%20in%20America">Football Night in America</a>". For the <a href="2009%20NFL%20season">2009 season</a>, <a href="Joe%20Theismann">Joe Theismann</a> and <a href="Joe%20Gibbs">Joe Gibbs</a> took Collinsworth's place in the booth for the first game of Wild Card Weekend. <a href="Andrea%20Kremer">Andrea Kremer</a> meanwhile, was the sideline reporter. The announcement of Joe Gibbs as one of the color commentators for the <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20NFL%20playoffs%23Wild%20Card%20playoffs">Wild Card Saturday playoff games</a> marked Gibbs' return to NBC's NFL coverage; where following his first retirement from the <a href="1992%20Washington%20Redskins%20season">Redskins</a>, he served as an occasional commentator on regional coverage during the <a href="1993%20NFL%20season">1993 NFL season</a> before becoming a <a href="List%20of%20NFL%20on%20NBC%20pregame%20show%20panelists">panelist</a> on "NFL Live!"/"NFL on NBC" between the <a href="1994%20NFL%20season">1994 season</a> until NBC lost their rights to cover the NFL after Super Bowl XXXII.
Beginning with the <a href="2010%20NFL%20season">2010 season</a>, NBC elected to use the Notre Dame football broadcast team as its #2 <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20NFL%20playoffs%23Wild%20Card%20playoffs">Wild Card Weekend</a> broadcast team, calling the early game, as <a href="Mike%20Mayock">Mike Mayock</a> and <a href="Alex%20Flanagan">Alex Flanagan</a> joined Tom Hammond. Dan Hicks filled in for Al Michaels on the <a href="2012%20NFL%20season">2012</a> <a href="NFL%20preseason">preseason</a> match-up between the <a href="2012%20Indianapolis%20Colts%20season">Indianapolis Colts</a> and the <a href="2012%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">Pittsburgh Steelers</a>. Al Michaels took some time off during that game after anchoring <a href="NBC%20Olympic%20broadcasts">NBC's daytime coverage</a> of the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="London">London</a>. Hicks also replaced Tom Hammond on the <a href="2012%20Notre%20Dame%20Fighting%20Irish%20football%20team">Notre Dame</a> broadcast team at this point.
The <a href="2013%20NFL%20season">2013 season</a> marked the last time that NBC would broadcast a <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20NFL%20playoffs%23Wild%20Card%20Playoffs">wild card playoff</a> <a href="Doubleheader%20%28television%29">doubleheader</a> for the foreseeable future. For <a href="2014%20NFL%20season">2014</a>, <a href="Monday%20Night%20Football">ESPN</a> aired one <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20NFL%20playoffs%23Wild%20Card%20Playoffs">wild card playoff game</a>, and from <a href="2015%20NFL%20season">2015</a> onward, <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> would <a href="simulcast">simulcast</a> ESPN's presentation of the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20NFL%20playoffs%23Wild%20Card%20Playoffs">wild card playoff game</a>. NBC would meanwhile, only air one wild card playoff game and one divisional playoff game.
2010s.
On December 14, 2011, the NFL, along with Fox, NBC and CBS, announced the league's rights deal with all three networks was extended to the end of the 2022 season. The three network rights deal includes the continued rotation of the Super Bowl yearly among the three, meaning NBC will air Super Bowls <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIX">XLIX</a> (2015), <a href="Super%20Bowl%20LII">LII</a> (2018), and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20LVI">LVI</a> (2022). The new rights deal also includes NBC receiving the primetime game of the Thanksgiving tripleheader previously carried by NFL Network, along with a divisional playoff game and one wild card game rather than the full Wild Card Saturday package.
NBC's broadcast of <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLVI">Super Bowl XLVI</a> at the end of the <a href="2011%20NFL%20season">2011 season</a> became the most-watched program in the history of <a href="Television%20in%20the%20United%20States">United States television</a>, with 111.3 million US viewers, according to <a href="Nielsen%20Company">Nielsen</a>. The game was the first Super Bowl telecast to be <a href="Streaming%20media">streamed</a> live online legally in the U.S., both to computers (via NFL.com and NBCSports.com) and mobile devices (via <a href="Verizon%20Wireless">Verizon Wireless</a>'s NFL Mobile <a href="Application%20software">app</a>). The game marked Al Michaels' eighth time conducting play-by-play for a Super Bowl (Michaels had previously done play-by-play for Super Bowls <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXII">XXII</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXV">XXV</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXIX">XXIX</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXIV">XXXIV</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXVII">XXXVII</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XL">XL</a> for ABC, and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIII">Super Bowl XLIII</a> for NBC).
<a href="NBC">NBC</a>'s television broadcast of the <a href="2012%20New%20England%20Patriots%20season">Patriots</a>-<a href="2012%20New%20York%20Jets%20season">Jets</a> game on November 22, <a href="2012%20NFL%20season">2012</a>, immediately following the now notorious "<a href="Butt%20Fumble">Butt Fumble</a>" play, <a href="color%20commentator">color commentator</a> <a href="Cris%20Collinsworth">Cris Collinsworth</a> said that "<a href="Vince%20Wilfork">Vince Wilfork</a> just threw <a href="Brandon%20Moore%20%28guard%29">Brandon Moore</a> into <a href="Mark%20Sanchez">Mark Sanchez</a>," a view simultaneously echoed on the <a href="New%20England%20Patriots%20Radio%20Network">Patriots radio call</a> by color analyst <a href="Scott%20Zolak">Scott Zolak</a>. Moore disagreed with Collinsworth: "when somebody slides into the back of you, you're going to fall. That happens a lot in general. You don't know what's going on (behind you)." Responding to Moore, Collinsworth qualified his description in a phone interview with <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a>, saying that Wilfork could see the play develop, so "instead of trying to go around Moore, he pushed him back into the play and made the whole thing happen." A "<a href="New%20York%20Daily%20News">New York Daily News</a>" columnist sided with Moore, stating that "A second look at the play shows Moore holding his own against Wilfork and moving, if anything, mostly forward."
NBC, which carried Thanksgiving afternoon games through 1997, did not issue an MVP award during that time. NBC began broadcasting the <a href="NFL%20on%20Thanksgiving%20Day">Thanksgiving</a> prime time game in 2012 (as part of its "Sunday Night Football" package), at which point the MVP award was added. The award is currently called the Sunday Night Football on Thanksgiving Night Player of the Game, and is typically awarded to multiple players on the winning team. From 2012 to 2015, the NBC award was referred to as the "Madden Thanksgiving Player-of-the-Game", honoring John Madden (who announced <a href="NBC%20Sunday%20Night%20Football">NBC</a> games from 2006 to 2008).
"Sunday Night Football" ranked the most-watched program in the United States during the 2011–12 season. This feat was repeated during the 2013–14 season; in that case, NBC finished the season as the #1 network among adults aged 18–49 for the first time since 2004 and #2 in total viewership (behind longtime leader CBS).
NBC's broadcast of <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIX">Super Bowl XLIX</a> at the end of <a href="2014%20NFL%20season">2014 season</a> became the most-watched program in the history of <a href="Television%20in%20the%20United%20States">United States Television</a>, with 114.4 million US viewers, according to <a href="Nielsen%20Company">Nielsen</a>. The game was the fourth overall telecast to be <a href="Streaming%20media">streamed</a> live online legally in the U.S. both to computers (via NFL.com and NBCSports.com) for the second time and mobile devices (via <a href="Verizon%20Wireless">Verizon Wireless</a>'s NFL Mobile <a href="Application%20software">app</a>). The game marked Al Michaels ninth time conducting play-by-play for a Super Bowl (Michaels had previously done play-by-play for Super Bowls <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXII">XXII</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXV">XXV</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXIX">XXIX</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXIV">XXXIV</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXVII">XXXVII</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XL">XL</a> for ABC and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIII">XLIII</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLVI">XLVI</a> for NBC).
NBC's coverage of <a href="Super%20Bowl%20LII">Super Bowl LII</a> between the <a href="2017%20Philadelphia%20Eagles%20season">Philadelphia Eagles</a> and <a href="2017%20New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a> at the end of the <a href="2017%20NFL%20season">2017 season</a> highlighted a play that would become known as the "<a href="Philly%20Special">Philly Special</a>". On the play, Philadelphia <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> <a href="Nick%20Foles">Nick Foles</a> moved up to behind his <a href="offensive%20line">offensive line</a> and the ball was directly <a href="Snap%20%28gridiron%20football%29">snapped</a> to <a href="running%20back">running back</a> <a href="Corey%20Clement">Corey Clement</a>. Clement went on to pitch the ball to <a href="Trey%20Burton">Trey Burton</a>, who passed the ball to a wide open Foles to score a <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>; Foles thereby became the first player in <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a> history to both throw and catch a touchdown. Eagles head coach <a href="Doug%20Pederson">Doug Pederson</a>'s decision to attempt to score a touchdown rather than attempt a <a href="field%20goal">field goal</a> on the play helped put the Eagles in a better position to defeat the <a href="2017%20New%20England%20Patriots%20season">New England Patriots</a>, which they subsequently did, 41–33. The victory was the Eagles' first championship in 57 years. Many analysts have since called the play one of the gutsiest play-calls in Super Bowl history. Before the play was called, Cris Collinsworth expressed his shock on-air that the Eagles would go for it, as he said, "This is an unbelievable call ... This is like going for an onside kick. This could decide the game." The game was the seventh overall telecast to be <a href="Streaming%20media">streamed</a> live online legally in the U.S. both to computers (via NFL.com and NBCSports.com) for the third time and mobile devices (via <a href="Verizon%20Wireless">Verizon Wireless</a>'s NFL Mobile <a href="Application%20software">app</a>). The game marked Al Michaels tenth time conducting play-by-play for a super bowl (Michaels previously done play-by-play for Super Bowls <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXII">XXII</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXV">XXV</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXIX">XXIX</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXIV">XXXIV</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XXXVII">XXXVII</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XL">XL</a> for ABC and Three More including <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIII">XLIII</a>, <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLVI">XLVI</a> and <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIX">XLIX</a> for NBC.)
In the between the <a href="2018%20Philadelphia%20Eagles%20season">Eagles</a> and <a href="2018%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">Chicago Bears</a>, Chicago kicker <a href="Cody%20Parkey">Cody Parkey</a> missed a 43-yard field goal attempt. The ball would hit the left upright, then bounce off the crossbar and fell to the end zone, no-good. Ultimately, the sixth-seeded Eagles won the game over the third-seeded Bears, 16–15 to advance to the divisional playoff round. The term "<a href="Double%20Doink">Double Doink</a>" took hold due to Cris Collinsworth, who said on the <a href="NBC">NBC</a> broadcast while he watched the replay, "The Bears' season's gonna end on a double doink." While Collinsworth is credited with coining the phrase "Double Doink." when asked about it the following day, he said, “I don’t think I invented the word; I think <a href="John%20Madden">John Madden</a> said doink first. But it was this double dinky thing — the ball bounced off one and then the other.”
On December 25, 2019, <a href="NFL%20Films">NFL Films</a> allowed two <a href="Western%20New%20York">Western New York</a> CBS affiliates owned by <a href="Nexstar%20Media%20Group">Nexstar Media Group</a>, <a href="Buffalo%2C%20New%20York">Buffalo</a>'s <a href="WIVB-TV">WIVB-TV</a> and <a href="Rochester%2C%20New%20York">Rochester</a>'s <a href="WROC-TV">WROC-TV</a>, to rerun the <a href="1990%E2%80%9391%20NFL%20playoffs">1990</a> <a href="AFC%20Championship%20Game">AFC Championship Game</a> as a <a href="Christmas">Christmas</a> special, in which the <a href="1990%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo Bills</a> defeated the then-<a href="1990%20Los%20Angeles%20Raiders%20season">Los Angeles Raiders</a>, 51–3. The telecast aired in its original <a href="standard-definition%20television">standard definition</a> format, though with <a href="NBC%20News">NBC News</a> updates regarding the <a href="Persian%20Gulf%20War">Persian Gulf War</a> and most references to <a href="NBC%20Sports">NBC Sports</a> outside natural game action edited out.
Thursday night games.
On February 1, 2016, the league announced that NBC had won a partial share of "<a href="Thursday%20Night%20Football">Thursday Night Football</a>" rights for the 2016 season; as a result, five additional Thursday night games (in addition the kickoff and Thanksgiving contests) in the later part of the season had been added to NBC's schedule. NBC Sports was also responsible for producing five games that was exclusive to <a href="NFL%20Network">NFL Network</a>. After the 2017 season, NBC insisted on a reduced rights fee in order to continue carrying "Thursday Night Football", which the NFL rejected; <a href="Fox%20NFL">Fox</a> was then awarded the rights to "Thursday Night Football" for the remainder of the time left on the league's broadcast contracts. NBC continued to carry the kickoff and Thanksgiving night games on Thursdays.
NBC often mixed their commentator groupings for 2016. Under league contract, Al Michaels and Cris Collinsworth called all of the games in the "<a href="Thursday%20Night%20Football">Thursday Night Football</a>" package that aired on NBC along with most Sunday nights. In general, <a href="Michele%20Tafoya">Michele Tafoya</a> served as sideline reporter for Sunday games and <a href="Heather%20Cox">Heather Cox</a> for Thursday games, with both sharing duties through the playoffs. <a href="Mike%20Tirico">Mike Tirico</a> called play-by-play for secondary games in Weeks 15 and 16, and filled in for Michaels for "SNF" assignments in Weeks 11 and 12. The NFL waived its contract requirement for the <a href="2017%20NFL%20season">2017 season</a>, allowing Mike Tirico to call all games on Thursdays, while Al Michaels remained on Sundays.
2020s.
<a href="Super%20Bowl%20LV">Super Bowl LV</a> was televised by <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a>. Although <a href="NBC%20Sunday%20Night%20Football">NBC</a> was to air this game under the current rotation, they traded with CBS for <a href="Super%20Bowl%20LVI">Super Bowl LVI</a>, which falls during the <a href="2022%20Winter%20Olympics">2022 Winter Olympics</a> and is the first to be scheduled during an ongoing Olympic Games (this also upholds the untold <a href="Gentlemen%27s%20agreement">gentleman's agreement</a> between the NFL's broadcasters to not <a href="Counterprogramming%20%28television%29">counterprogram</a> the Super Bowl, as NBC also holds the U.S. broadcast rights to the Olympics). CBS, to an extent, also benefited from holding rights to the Super Bowl in the same year that it held rights to the <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">NCAA Final Four</a> (which is cycled with <a href="WarnerMedia">WarnerMedia</a> Entertainment channels on a two-year cycle, and CBS had also broadcast in the same year as its <a href="Super%20Bowl%20LIII">previous Super Bowl</a>).
With the NFL expanding its Wild Card round to six games in the <a href="2020%20NFL%20season">2020 season</a>, broadcast rights to the new games were sold to <a href="NFL%20on%20CBS">CBS</a> and <a href="NBC%20Sunday%20Night%20Football">NBC</a>, at approximately $70 million each. Both networks announced plans to <a href="simulcast">simulcast</a> their games on other outlets owned by their parent companies, with NBC planning to simulcast its game on its recently-launched streaming service <a href="Peacock%20%28streaming%20service%29">Peacock</a>, and on its Spanish-language broadcast network <a href="Telemundo">Telemundo</a>.
The 2020 schedule was released on May 7. The Kickoff game was on September 10, which featured the <a href="Super%20Bowl%20LIV">Super Bowl LIV</a> Champion <a href="2020%20Kansas%20City%20Chiefs%20season">Kansas City Chiefs</a> hosting the <a href="2020%20Houston%20Texans%20season">Houston Texans</a>. The Thanksgiving Night game was supposed to feature the <a href="2020%20Baltimore%20Ravens%20season">Baltimore Ravens</a> against the <a href="2020%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">Pittsburgh Steelers</a>; the ninth time that the Thanksgiving game would have been part of the "SNF" package shown on NBC. A COVID-19 outbreak on the Baltimore Ravens forced the postponement of the game to the following Sunday afternoon, which was then postponed to the following Tuesday night, and then finally to Wednesday afternoon. It was shown on NBC as scheduled, but <a href="KWQC-TV">KWQC-TV</a> - the NBC affiliate for the <a href="Quad%20Cities">Quad Cities</a> of Iowa and Illinois - opted not to show the game. Before this occasion, the last Wednesday night game played in the NFL was also a special edition of primetime on NBC - the 2012 Kickoff game between the <a href="2012%20Dallas%20Cowboys%20season">Dallas Cowboys</a> and <a href="2012%20New%20York%20Giants%20season">New York Giants</a> that was scheduled as such to avoid a conflict with Barack Obama's renomination speech at <a href="2012%20Democratic%20National%20Convention">that year's Democratic National Convention</a>.
Mike Tirico substituted for Al Michaels on a select number of games this season, that started with the September 27 game between the <a href="2020%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">Green Bay Packers</a> and the <a href="2020%20New%20Orleans%20Saints%20season">New Orleans Saints</a>. Tirico was initially slated to call the Thanksgiving game this season, but was assigned instead to call the Week 12 "SNF" game between the Packers and the <a href="2020%20Chicago%20Bears%20season">Chicago Bears</a> with <a href="Tony%20Dungy">Tony Dungy</a> and <a href="Kathryn%20Tappen">Kathryn Tappen</a>. Tirico was eventually given the assignment to call the rescheduled Ravens–Steelers game with Collinsworth after it was postponed from Sunday afternoon to Wednesday night. Tirico is also slated to call one of NBC’s two wild card playoff games in January.
The aforementioned Packers–Saints game took place while the <a href="2020%20Stanley%20Cup%20Finals">2020 Stanley Cup Finals</a> (rescheduled from its normal late May–early June schedule) were ongoing; As NBC was also the <a href="NHL%20on%20NBC">rightsholder</a> to <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">National Hockey League</a> games in the U.S., the league opted to play Games 4 and 5 (September 25–26) of the finals on consecutive nights to avoid conflict with "SNF". In addition, the <a href="2020%20NBA%20Finals">2020 NBA Finals</a> were also moved from June to October due to the pandemic. "SNF" games were played on the same night as NBA Finals in consecutive weeks, on October 4 (<a href="2020%20Philadelphia%20Eagles%20season">Philadelphia</a> vs. <a href="2020%20San%20Francisco%2049ers%20season">San Francisco</a>) the same day as Game 3, and on October 11 (Minnesota vs. Seattle) on the same day as Game 6 (the eventual last game of the series).
On March 18, 2021, the NFL, along with Fox, NBC, CBS and ESPN announced the league's rights deal with all four networks was extended through the 2033 season. The four network rights deal includes the rotation of the Super Bowl yearly among the four, meaning NBC will air Super Bowls Super Bowl LX (2026), LXIV (2030) and LXVIII (2034).
